bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, December 11, 1941

div1.p: Hench informs Wood that he does not know Reed's whereabouts in 1893. He suggests she contact Wilson. He notes that his book does not focus on individuals to the extent that her work does.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Laura Wood, December 11, 1941
div1.opener:
Y. F.
December 11, 1941
Miss Laura Wood
1338 19th Street N. W.
Washington, D. C.
My dear Miss Wood:
div1.p:
I am glad the Kelly books arrived. There is no particular hurry
about returning the third edition.

Since I am writing the story of the Cuban episode from the human
angle and not the story of any individual participant, I have not done much
on the researches of any of the individual men. Therefore, I cannot help
you much as to the whereabouts of Reed in 1893. However, Dr. Louis B. Wilson,
Director Emeritus of the Mayo Foundation, can help you, I am sure. I am sending
you a reprint of his which shows his connection with Dr. Reed in St. Paul. Yes-
terday he gave me the following additional information after I permitted him to
read your letter.

While still studying medicine, Dr. Wilson was teaching biology in the
Central High School in St. Paul. On March 28, 1893 Dr. Wilson met Reed, who there-
after used Wilson's microscope and laboratory. Dr. Wilson insists that Reed
stayed in St. Paul until November, 1893. Dr. Wilson certifies to the date of
March 28 because that is the date given by Reed himself in the reprint. August
was vacation time for Wilson. Having met Reed in March, by May, 1893, Reed and
Wilson began making throat swabs and worked on this during the summer time.
They continued to work together even after Dr. Wilson's school started in Septem-
ber, 1893, and worked together for three more months until Reed was transferred
to Washington in November, 1893. Dr. Wilson said it is of course possible that
Reed left town from time to time between March and November, 1893, but during those
months at least he was officially in St. Paul. Reed had been at Hopkins before
coming to St. Paul and may have gone to Hopkins after he left St. Paul. Dr. Wilson
says that Sternberg did not send Reed to Hopkins in May, 1893. He may have made
the arrangements at that time, but Wilson is sure that Reed did not go in that month.
A few years later, in 1898, Reed returned to Minneapolis I believe to speak or at
least attend a meeting there. Dr. Wilson thought it was the meeting of the American
Public Health Association (do you know whether he attended that meeting?). At any
rate, Reed was a house guest of Dr. Wilson in their home at 1004 Como Avenue at the
corner of Sixteenth Street in Minneapolis. During their conversations, Reed inquired
of Wilson as to whether Wilson would like to leave Minneapolis and join him in Wash-
ington and do bacteriology in the Army Medical Corps. It so happened that Dr. Wilson
and Dr. Westbrook were studying an epidemic of typhoid fever among the thirteenth
regiment of Minnesota volunteers encamped at the State Fair Grounds in St. Paul.
Wilson and Westbrook noted that latrines were close to the kitchens and they actually
watched flies going from one to the other. They caught flies but were unable to
Miss Laura Wood
- 2 -
December 11, 1941
find typhoid bacilli thereon. Reed was much interested in this work and you
know a little bit later he was put on the committee with Vaughan and Shakespeare,
which proved the carrier ability of flies in typhoid fever. Dr. Wilson declined
Major Reed's suggestion because he (Wilson) wanted to finish his work with West-
brook. Dr. Wilson doesn't remember where Reed lived in St. Paul in 1893 but he
had his laboratory in a government building on the south side of Third Street
either at Roberts or Cedar Streets, St. Paul. The building has been torn down
long since.

This is all Dr. Wilson could remember yesterday. He gold me that he
would be glad to hear from you if he could help in any further way. I am sending
him a copy of this letter in order that he can check up on me if I have misquoted
him.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
